nodes.text: The empirical and methodological contributions of David Card, Joshua Angrist, and Guido Imbens transformed modern applied microeconomics by promoting design-based causal inference using natural experiments and formalizing interpretation of instrumental variables
Selection bias is a central empirical challenge in economics: treated and untreated groups differ for reasons that confound causal estimates and randomized experiments are often infeasible

Design-based approach: identify sources of plausibly as-good-as-random variation (natural experiments), construct appropriate comparison groups, and make identifying assumptions explicit to improve internal validity
David Card applied design-based natural experiments to labour questions, producing surprising empirical findings that challenged conventional wisdom

Angrist and Imbens formalized IV estimation in a potential outcomes framework and derived the Local Average Treatment Effect (LATE) result clarifying what IV estimates identify under minimal assumptions
The potential outcomes framework separates random assignment of an instrument from substantive assumptions (exclusion, monotonicity, relevance) and permits treatment effect heterogeneity

Design-based studies require careful assessment of internal validity (identifying causal eï¬€ects for the study population) and raise external validity concerns when generalizing to other populations or policies

The laureates' combined empirical and methodological work strengthened empirical practice by tying institutional knowledge to identification, encouraging tailored data collection, sensitivity checks, and synthesis across designs

Card (1990) used the 1980 Mariel boatlift as a natural experiment and found little detectable impact of a large low-skill immigrant inflow on native wages and employment in Miami relative to comparable cities

Card and Krueger (1994) exploited New Jersey's 1992 minimum wage increase with a border comparison and store-level survey and found no evidence of employment declines in fast-food restaurants in New Jersey relative to Pennsylvania

Angrist and Krueger (1991) used quarter-of-birth as an instrument for schooling and reported IV estimates implying about a 10 percent earnings return per additional year of schooling, illustrating narrow IV variation from birthdate

Imbens and Angrist (1994) showed the standard IV (Wald) estimand identifies the LATE: the average treatment effect for compliers (those whose treatment is changed by the instrument) under random assignment, exclusion, monotonicity, and relevance

The LATE/result implies IV estimates reflect internal validity for instrument-affected subpopulations and must be combined with structural assumptions or alternative designs to answer broader policy questions (external validity)
